author: Rebecca Smithers
title: Britons shop as if they're on holiday – little and often | Business
text:
Seismic changes in British shopping habits mean that half of us now buy our food as we do when on holiday – little and often, stocking up daily with fresh food for that evening’s meal, according to a study.
In its annual barometer of consumer shopping and spending , the food retailer Waitrose found that three in 10 people now visit a supermarket three to four times a week, up from a quarter five years ago.
But the “open all hours” culture on the UK high street and freedom to shop in different ways also means that consumers admit to being daunted by choice, whether for informal dining, music streaming or TV on demand. They are opting to regain control by reimposing boundaries such as keeping certain nights free to eat together, or banning mobile phones from the dining table.
You can have a sit-down meal in a supermarket and buy your dinner in a petrol station. It can be overwhelming
Mark Price
Launching the chain’s Food and Drink Report 2015 on Wednesday, Waitrose’s managing director, Mark Price, said the shift in behaviour was characterised by time-poor consumers buying food on the go and for the evening ahead. In London, 40% of Waitrose sales are after 5pm, for example, as people grab dinner on the way home from work.
Top-ups used to be unplanned; now they’re deliberate Price , who is stepping down from the chain next April and is tipped to become Channel 4 chairman , said: “As society changes, so does the nature of shopping. It is more informal and flexible than ever before. High streets are seeing significant changes: today you can get a panini in a newsagent, a newspaper in a coffee shop, have a sit-down meal in a supermarket and buy your dinner in a petrol station. It can be overwhelming.”
Jon Arnold, Waitrose head of operations and trading, convenience, added: “It used to be that ‘topping up’ in a convenience store was unplanned and not particularly desired. But now shoppers deliberately work it into their weekly routine. They buy bulky food online, or all in one go, and then nip out in the week to buy dinner for that night.”
Facebook Twitter Pinterest The first Oxo TV advert, screened in 1983. Mealtimes today are more informal than ever, the report says
The report’s findings are based on millions of transactions and feedback from Waitrose customers, as well as separate sessions with focus groups and further polling on a range of food-related topics.
Waitrose this year revealed plans to create 2,000 jobs as it embarks on a store-opening spree following strong Christmas trading. The retailer, owned by the John Lewis Partnership, is opening a further 14 shops this year, split between supermarkets and Little Waitrose convenience shops.
Related: Customer shopping habits pop back to the 70s, says John Lewis
In the report, a third of consumers say that “pausable” TVs and services such as Netflix and iPlayer mean fewer TV dinners in our homes. Yet mealtimes are more informal than ever: one in seven families use their dining room less than they used to, while a quarter of us regularly eat “al fresco”.
Microwave rules the kitchen roost In its spotlight on specific food and drink trends, the report reveals the impact of gadgets on specialist ingredients. Waitrose now sells more pre-chopped frozen fruit than frozen pizza thanks to the rise of juicing, while the spiraliser craze, which turns courgettes into ribbons, or courgetti, has boosted sales of the vegetable by 10% over the past year. Nevertheless, the microwave still rules the kitchen roost, with half of all consumers surveyed saying they use it more than any other gadget.
This year’s mild winter and early spring have produced bumper UK crops, including the earliest-ever start to the British strawberry season in March. British-produced rapeseed oil – including brands such as Hillfarm in east Suffolk as well as Waitrose’s own brand – has elbowed aside pricier olive oil as the fastest-selling oil in the UK.
Facebook Twitter Pinterest Avocado is the most pinned food on Pinterest, and roasted tomato and avocado toast is the fourth most watched recipe on Waitrose’s YouTube channel. Photograph: Hisham Ibrahim/Getty
Social media are also becoming increasingly influential for food choices. Avocado is the most pinned food on Pinterest in the UK, while roasted tomato and avocado toast is the fourth most watched recipe on the Waitrose TV channel on YouTube.
For the older generation, food has become “exciting where it was once functional”. Waitrose reports that newly retired men are signing up in large numbers to its cookery school courses. Claire Lanze, head chef of the Waitrose cookery school in Salisbury, Wiltshire, said: “They’re one of our fastest growing student groups, so we’ve started trialling courses aimed specifically at them.”
